title: What forms do I use to response back to being served with form SUM-100 and CM-010 in a Civil case regarding debt owed?
question: I was sued by a creditor for a uncollateralized personal loan
answers: you need to contact a lawyer to review your documents and file an appriopriate response raising all possible defenses.

You have been served with a summons and a complaint. No form is appropriate to for response. You must respond with fact specific pleading within time specified on summons and complaint or you may be defaulted. Consult debt collection defense counsel.

I am reluctant to recommend to anyone to go at it by themselves because of the risks that it won't be done right. However if you are determined to take this route note that there are number of resources just be prepared to commit to spending time researching and figuring things out.
Here is a link to Sacramento County Public Library discussing Answering a Complaint.
http://www.saclaw.org/pages/responding-lawsuit.aspx
Your local regular library might have some information but best bet is to visit the San Diego Public Law Library and spend time with their materials for the Do It Yourself. http://sandiegolawlibrary.org/about-us/whats-here/#selfhelpmaterials

There are no specific forms to respond to a lawsuit. You should seek a consultation with a qualified debt defense attorney in your area, and/or a bankruptcy lawyer. Better yet, try to find one who handles both debt defense litigation and bankruptcy law. The attorney will evaluate the lawsuit and your overall financial situation and recommend the best course of action.

It is very important that you contact a lawyer as soon as possible. You have a limited time during which to file and serve your response. If you don't then the creditor could win by default. An attorney can file a response and start the negotiation process. You've been sued. You should contact a lawyer.
This is a summons and complaint. You can either cal them and negotiate --I would)-- or answer (say, if you have a defense such as the statute of limitations) or default.
